question: 1 (a)
sols_html: For \(f\)(x) to pass through all the data points, we must have pn(xn) = yn and for \(f\)(x) to be continuous, we must have pn(xn+1) = yn+1. Each of these give us N-1 equations because there are N-1 polynomials. So in total, (N-1) + (N-1) = 2N - 2 equations.
sols_latex:

\emph{p\textsubscript{n}(x\textsubscript{n}) = y\textsubscript{n}} and
for \emph{$f$(x)} to be continuous, we must have
\emph{p\textsubscript{n}(x\textsubscript{n+1}) = y\textsubscript{n+1}}.
Each of these give us \emph{N-1} equations because there are \emph{N-1}
polynomials. So in total, \emph{(N-1) + (N-1) = 2N - 2} equations.

statement_html:
Suppose you are given a set of N data points (xn, yn), with xn increasing, and you wish to interpolate these points with a spline function \(f\), where \(f\)(x) is given by the cubic polynomial pn(x) on each interval (xn, xn+1) for n = 1, ..., N-1:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p_n(x) = a_n(x-x_n)^3 + b_n(x-x_n)^2 + c_n(x-x_n) + d_n\end{aligned}\]

(a) Write down the equations required for \(f\)(x) to be continuous and to pass through the data points. How many equations does this provide?
